newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Hungarian prime minister confident on NATO.
newsitem.headline: Hungarian prime minister confident on NATO.

text.p: Hungarian Prime Minister Gyula Horn said on Saturday he was confident the basic issues in negotiations between Russia and NATO to strike a deal on a new relationship had been settled.

"I think that the meeting between (Russian President Boris) Yeltsin and (U.S. President Bill) Clinton in Helsinki finally, eventually, as far as the essence of the matter is concerned has settled the basic outstanding issues," Horn told Reuters.
Yeltsin and Clinton met in Helsinki in March.

NATO and Russia are hurrying to complete a charter on their relations before a July summit of the Western alliance which will open the door for former Warsaw Pact states in Eastern Europe, including Hungary, to apply for NATO membership.
Yeltsin said in Germany on Thursday that the charter agreement would be signed on May 27 in Paris. But the United States says the document is far from complete.
Diplomats and analysts in Brussels have said Russia is demanding strict limits on what new members can do, and some have said a deal is far from certain.
Horn was commenting after a news conference winding up a four-day visit to Singapore.
